South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

be marked Via Eastern.

bulletin in this paper.

Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: MONDAY, APRIL 9, 1906. ISLAM IN INDIA.
div.p: Mobamedanism is still a great force in India It is the faith of one person out of every five in the country, write* Mr. Sidney Low in ‘'The Standard." The King rules more than half the Mohamedan population of the world, the Sultan of Turkey coming a very long way behind him. There is one province—that of the North-West Frontier—which is almost entirely Mohamedan, the Hindus being an unimportant minority. In the Punjab Mohamedans an numerous, and they are to be found scattered everywhere down to the extreme sooth, especially in the towns. In Eastern Bengal there are some twenty-eight millions of them, and here they increase more rapidly than the Hindus; for the Mussulman, with his varied diet, has a better physique than the pulse and grain-feeding Brahmanists, and, moreover, be does not believe in child marriages, nor does he think it wrong for widows to re-marry. The high and growing proportion of the Mohamedan population in Bengal is one of the hard nuts for the Bengalis to crack. It is also an elementary fact which is not generally appreciated. By race these Bengal Mohamedans are akin to the Hindus, and that, indeed, is true of the great majority of their co-religionists outside the Frontier province. Most of them are descended from Hindus who were converted daring the long period of Moslem role. They exist as a standing argument against the modern doctrine which ascribes everything to race, and nothing to environment, education, social conditions, and custom. Islam has developed the character of the Indian Mohamedan somewhat at the expense of hi* intellect He is simpler, braver, more mas-online, more devout, in a rough, practical, straightforward fashion, hot he is less subtle, less ingenious, less acute, and far less capable of assimilating the methods of modern educa-tion. He makes a first-rate soldier, a good policeman, inspector, or watchman, and be does fairly well in any post when courage, fidelity, and a certain self respect and requisite he has a distinct aptitude for trade, and as a shopkeeper be is frequently very successful. He is a convenient man to bare a butler or personal servant, for in the tint place be is in moderation honest, and secondly, he is not under the tyranny of caste rules, and can serve food to a Christian without a qualm. Bat the Hindu beats him at the office and the desk, and in the class-room. This is one of the reasons why there ought not to be direct appointments to the higher Civil Service by competitive examination in India. It is quite certain that in this contest the babu and the Brahman would beat the Mohamedan out of the field. Most Indian Mussulmans cherish in their hearts some memory of the days when their fathers were the masters of India, and they believe that, if ever the English power were shaken, they would regain their old predominance. In the meanwhile the Mohamedans will endure being the subjects of a Christian race, whose character they respect, and whose religion they can understand. But to The feebler tribes of idol-worshippers, as they consider them, they protest indignantly that it would be an outrage to ask them to yield obedience.

LOCAL AND GENERAL. GERMANY,TURKEY, AND EGYPT THE KHEDIVE. GREEK INDEPENDENCE DAY. COUNCIL OF MINISTERS. , The Plague Another case of plague is reported from Keneh. Cairo French Hospital- Mme. Beyerlé has presented the French Hospital in Cairo with £200 for the endow¬ment of a bed in memory of her late husband. Ethel Pain Memorial Hospital. The Earl and Countess of Meath will inspect the new building of the Ethel Pain Memorial Hospital at Old Cairo on Saturday, 14th inst. Excelsiorl Rumours are afloat that the projected hotel opposite the Savoy will be called the Excelsior. Let us hope it will belie its name. We have enough sky-scrapers in Cairo and the sun is our best disinfectant Weather in Upper Egypt. Our Luxor Correspondent telegraphs that the temperature at Luxor on Saturday at 9 а. m. was 66 deg. and at noon 73 deg. Fahrenheit, which is remarkably cool for the time of year. University for Alexandria. The Council of Ministers has decided to grant a large plot of Government land - 24,000 metres in area—situated at Gabbari, to the Alexandria Ulema Board, for the purpose of building a large religious university. Charge of Assault. This morning, Spiro Ellul was brought up at the British Consular Court, Cairo, on a charge of wounding Raffaele Grech Cumbo on Saturday, 31st ulto. The proceedings were not concluded at the time our reporter telephoned. Hashish Seizure. The Coast Guards seized 67 kilos of hashish as the drug was being lowered from a boat in Alexandria harbour on Saturday. The weight of the hashish which was discovered by them in the eastern harbour, as reported in oar last issue, was no less than 1,045 kilos. Wilson Pacha’s Will. Mr. James Wilson (Wilson Pacha), of 19, Lymington-road, Hampstead, and formerly of Cairo, who died on February 24, left estate valued at £20,141 15s. gross, in the United Kingdom, the net personalty being sworn at £19,872 4s. 7d. Probate of his will dated March 22, 1881, has been granted to his widow, Mrs. Annie Wilson, of 19, Lymington- road, to whom he left the whole of his estate absolutely. Luncheon on the Pyramids. Moonlight parties to Mena House Hotel are as popular as ever, not with standing that there has been a great exodus from Cairo. Mr. Sloman and a party were quite early at Mena House Hotel on Saturday. Mr. Sloman had invited some friends to climb the Pyramids. The party went up accompanied by a crowd of servants, who Carried luncheon baskets and wine cases, and had lunch on top of the big Pyramid. The whole party returned afterwards to Mena House Hotel and had dinner there. Institution for the Blind at Zeitoun. It may interest many of our readers to know that the concert given in aid of the above institution at Shepheard's Hotel on the 21st March last was a financial success. We have been favoured with a oopy of the report of the oommittee from which we gather that the total receipts were P.T. 7,500 and the expenses P.T. 1,118, leaving a balance of P.T. 6,382, which amount has been duly handed over to the president of the committee of the institution, who, in acknowledging the receipt of the cheque, thanks the promoters, the artistes, and all who gave their services, for their very great kindness in so substantially aiding a most deserving charity. Murder Will Out. THE SULTAN AND TA BAH. HOW TO REOPEN THE EGYPTIAN QUESTION. (Gazette’s Special Service.) LONDON, Monday. The “Daily Telegraph’s” Correspondent at Constantinople says that well-informed Turk- ish circles attribute the Saltan’s obstinancy over the Tabah affair to the suggestions of Germany, who is trying to persuade him to ask for the arbitration of The Hague Tribunal, thus reopening the whole Egyptian question, with a prospect of the ultimate recovery of the province. Our contemporary "Al Mokattam” states that Turkish poets are now established all along the line from Gaza to Akaba and are stopping caravans on the frontier. Our con¬temporary adds that a number of traders and Bedouins have been robbed by these warriors. MARCH TRADE RETURNS. ( Gazette’s Special Service ). LONDON, Monday. The trade returns for. March show increases exceeding 4 1/4 millions in imports and 3 1/2 in exports. ANOTHER DEATH-DEALING WEAPON. (Gazette’s Special Service ) LONDON, Saturday. The “Echo de Paris”to-day reports the dis-covery of a marvellous invention of a quick- firing gun by an Artillery officer, which is capable of firing 600 shots a minute. The bullets, instead of being concentrated in one direction, are distributed over a radius of 160 degrees. AMERICAN MINERS PROPOSE ARBITRATION. ( Gazette’s Special Service ) LONDON, Saturday. The “Times” Correspondent at New York states that the coal miners have proposed arbi-tration. They are taking this step, it is said, in view of the great public interests which are involved. AMERICAN STOCKS & SHARES. (Gazette’s Special Service.) NEW YORK, Saturday. Yesterday To-day Aitchison. ... 96} 96} Baltimore & Ohio 116} 117J Canadian Pacific ... 177} 1781 Chicago and Milwaukee ... 182} 183 JBrie... ... 46} 46J Illinois Central ... 178} 178} Louisville ... 155} 155} New York Central ... 150 150} Pennsylvania Shares ... ... 72J 73 Philadelphia and Reading ... 70} 71} Southern Pacifi) ... ... ... 60} 71} Union Paoifio ... 152} 163} U.S. Steel. ... ... 43J 44 „ Pre£ ... 101} 101} GHARBIEH LAND COMPANY. We bear that the emission of shares of this new company has been a great success, being covered more than three times over. PRINCE OF WALES’ PROMISE. PROBABLE VISIT TO LONDON. HELLENIC MUNIFICENCE. INTERESTING CEREMONY. SATURDAY’S DECISIONS. LAKE MENZALEH TAXES ABOLISHED. H. H. the Khedive has fixed his depar¬ture from Cairo for Alexandria for Monday, the 30th inst. The usual reception previous to his leaving the Capital will be held on either Thursday, the 26th, or Saturday, the 28th instant. We understand that his Highness has invit-ed T.R.H. the Prince and Princess of Wales to pay Egypt another and a longer visit at some future time, which invitation the Royal couple accepted. It is rumoured that the Khedive will in all probability pay a visit to London this summer at the invitation of his Royal visitors. KHEDIVE ENTERTAINS THB ARCHDUKE On Friday last the Khedive gave a small afternoon party at Koubbeh, the guests being T.R.H. the Archduke Joseph and the Arch- duchess Augusta, the Archduke’s Chamberlain and physician, and the lady-in-waiting of the Archduchess, Count Koziebrodski, the Austro- Hungarian Minister, General Thurneyssen Pacha, A.D.C., and Mme Baltazzi Stockan and her daughter, in all, with the Khedive, 10 per¬sons. The party first drove round the stables and admired the Khedive’s fine stud, then drove over to the fields to watch the horses eating bersim, and subsequently proceeded to Monstourouh, the other pro-perty of the Khedive, close to Koub- beh, where tea bad been prepared. Afterwards the Khedive accompanied his guests back to Koubbeh. It was a delightful afternoon, and on Saturday morning, when General Thurneys¬sen Pacha went to the station to see the Archduke off on behalf of the Khedive, the Archduke and Archduchess asked him to present the expression of their thankfulness to the Khecfive for the pleasant afternoon they had passed with him. The Khedive has made a gift of a thorough¬bred Arab to the Archduchess. THE PILGRIMAGE. Ibrahim Pasha Fathy’s report on the pilgrim¬age will in all probability be published in the near future. The Hag has been a thorough success from every point of view—save that of some of the Bedonins—and not a single Egyp¬tian pilgrim, soldier or official, has fallen a victim to the lawless tribes of the Hedjaz. THE HEDJAZ RAILWAY. We bear that the Ottoman authorities are pushing this railway forward as rapidly as pos sible S. of Qala’ at Medawara towards Tebonk. The line will pass through Tebouk and Qala” at El Akbdar and will then enter a depression with easy gradients and free from any great engineering difficulties till Medina is reached. Herr Meissner, the able German engineer, to whom the construction of the line is mainly due, has been recently on a visit to railhead On the 25th of last month, on the occasion of the holding of the weekly market at El Ham- mam, a murder was committed at some dis- tance from that village, a Bedeuin having been found shot in the head. The police took the matter in hand, but until yesterday no trace of the murderer could be found. Yesterday was again the market day and a polioe officer belong¬ing to the Mariout district who was on duty there received information to the effect that the murderer, a Bedouin like his victim, was to be found at Sidi Gaber. He at once proceeded by train in company with his informant, who pointed the man out near Sidi Gaber caraool. The murderer was thereupon arrested and in bis possession was found a new revolver with six chambers loaded, besides twelve rounds of ammunation. It appears that the man, know¬ing his viotim to possess a large sum of money, had followed him after the fair and, taking the opportunity of his being asleep in a field, had shot him through the head, afterwards taking a sum of about £70 off the body. Spend your Holidays at Mena, The management of Mena House Hotel has arranged" special terms for residents of Cairo, Alexandria, and country from the 10th of April to the 10th of May. [Advt.] THE 8UCRERIES. MM. Herschitz and Roux de Vence have now entered on their functions as co syndics. The Parquet is at present busily engaged in examin¬ing the records of the Sucreries. THE CRONIER BILLS. A meeting of the shareholders of the Orleans Railway Company was held in Paris last week, when the question of the Cronier bills was discussed. It was unanimously acknowledged that the Board of Directors did not act against the statutes by discounting there bills with the reserve funds of the company, although it was admitted that the operation was attended with disastrous results. At the meeting of the Seciete Generale, held the same day, the Cronier bills were also men¬tioned; but before the question could be developed, the chairman announced that the managing director of the Société Generale had already resigned the directorship of the unfor¬tunate Egyptian Sugar Refineries, as well as of other ventures, and would in future devote himself exclusively to the steadily-increasing affairs of the bank. PORT SUDAN AND KHARTOUM WATER SUPPLY. Some time ago the Artesian Boring and Prospecting Company received from the Sudan Government the contract for the installation of water supplies by means of artesian wells to the towns of Khartoum and Port Sudan. With regard to the latter place they have just received a telegram . from their residing engineer informing them that up-to-date their steam-driven “Express Boring’’ plant has reached a depth of 400 feet with a first bore¬hole, and that already this artesian well is able to supply a certain quantity of fresh water to the inhabitants of Port Sadan. There seems to be no doubt that the source of the water comes from the mountains situated in the neighbourhood of the town, as the level of the water in the bore-well rises to a con¬siderable height above the sea level If, how. ever, the output is not sufficient further borings are intended to be made in order to ensure all the necessary supply of water which may eventually be required. With regard to Khartoum, the company’s installation for the supply of fresh water to the whole. town, also by means of artesian wells, is on the point of being finished, by means of wells driven to a depth between 250 and 350 feet. In the course of the works the company have encountered stratas of excellent Nubian sandstone, which will ensure a supply of the best pare water. CARLTON HOTEL, STEAMER MOVEMENTS. . The S.S. Sailor Prince, from Antwerp and London, with passengers and general cargo, left Malta on Saturday, and is due at Alex-andria on Wednesday morning next. Beck & Co’s Pilsener Beer. BREMEN. LTD A CHAPTER OF ACCIDENTS. A native boy, while playing with some other boys in the Mohatrem Bey quarter yesterday, was run over by a passing cart and succumbed a few hours afterwards to bis injuries. A native youth of 17 was run overby a tram- car yesterday on the Mex line, while he was attempting to cross the rails. He was promptly taken to hospital, bat expired a short time after wards. Some natives who were witnesses of the accident attacked the driver and conductor of the tram and beat them unmercifully, causing them severe injuries. A native, aged 65 years, was bathing in the sea yesterday near the Alexandria Slaughter¬house, when he was carried out of his depth by the waves and was drowned. His body was recovered. The celebration of the anniversary of the declaration of Greek independence on Satur¬day last will long be remembered by the Greek oolony at Alexandria, for the occasion was made use of for laying the foundation-stone of an institution which is destined to be one of the finest educational establishments in Egypt. The former president of the Hellenic com-munity of Alexandria, the late Mr. Constan¬tino Salvago, left a bequest in bis will for the purpose of founding a polytechnic here. After his death the bequest was largely in¬creased by the generosity of Mr. Salvago’s widow and two sons. A large plot of land was bought ourside Rosetta-gate, in front of the cemeteries, and yesterday afternoon the foun-dation stone of the institution was laid by Mrs. Argentina Michel Salvago, in the pre¬sence of a great concourse of members of the Greek colony and representatives of the other European colonies. A large tent was set np for the occasion, where a sumptuous buffet was prepared. At 4.30 o’olock the ceremony began with a thanks¬giving service, conducted by the Greek Ortho¬dox Patriarch'Photius I., assisted by all his clergy. The Patriarch, at the conclusion of the service, invoked the blessing of the Most High on the new school by sprinkling holy water, and finished an eloquent harangue with an account of the many acts of generosity by which the Greek colony of Alexandria had benefited owing to the munificence of its wealthy members. After the Patriarch Mr. Paleologos Georgiou, the headmaster of the Hellenic community’s sohools, read from a parchment document the formal bequest of the donors, which was afterwards signed by Photius I, Mohamed Bey Hafez, Acting Governor of Alexandria, Mr. N. Scotidis, Hellenic Consul-General, Mr. E. B. Gould, H.B.M.’s Consol General for the City and Port of Alexandria, Schiess Pacha, Vice-President of the Alexandria Municipality, Chataway Bey, Administrator of the Alex¬andria Municipality, Mr. Emmanuel Benachi and Mr. Michael Sinadino, the President and Vice-President of the Hellenic community, Messrs. Michael and Steffy Salvago, Mrs. Constantino Salvago, and Mrs Argentina Miohel Salvago. The parchment was looked in a metal tube and placed in the orifice of the foundation-stone together with a copy of thp “Egyptian Gazette” and the “Harmonia” of the day’s date, besides some specimens of oar- rent Egyptian coins. Mrs. Argentina Michel Salvago then advanced and, after christen¬ing the stone with the contents of two bottles of champagne, received a beauti- fnlly-chased silver trowel, a mallet, and a hammer, presented by the well-known Italian engineer, Signor Diamanti, and then proceeded to declare the stone “well and truly laid.” A buffalo was then brought forward and sacrificed on the foundation-stone. The beast was afterwards cat up and its flesh distributed to the poor. The fine band of the Alexandria Hellenic community played meanwhile a choice selection of music, and the stone was lowered into its position amidst the acclamations of the assembled multitude. The President of the Hellenic commnnity, Mr. Emmanuel Benachi, then made an eloquent speech wherein he called to mind the good deeds of the benefactors of the Greek colony of Alexandria, such as the late George Averoff and the late Constantine Salvago, whose noble example was to-day being followed by the surviving members of the family of his predecessor, the late president of the com¬munity. Mr. Benschi then declared that the Hellenic colony was shortly to benefit by another act of generosity, for Mr. George Zervudaohi has decided to build at his own expense a Normal College here. The speaker went on to announce that be would follow Mr. Zervndachi’s example by endowing the Hellenio oolony with an orphan¬age. At these unexpected announcements there was a great outburst of cheering and the crowd rent the air with their acclamations of pleasure at these acts of generosity. Mr. N. Scotidis, Hellenic Consul-General at Alexandria, then prononnoed a brilliant speech, thanking the donors of these splendid gifts in the name of the Greeks of Alexandria. He .begged the wealthy members of his race to follow these magnifioent precedents, and to set an example of generosity and public spirit whereby the Hellenic commnnity throughout Egypt would ever march in the van of pro¬gress. Mr. Miohel Salvago thanked all the spea¬kers on behalf of his mother, his brother, and himself, declaring that be was merely obeying the orders given by his late father in his will, and be hoped that he and his family wonld hereafter follow the example set by his father in doing other works for the good of his compatriots in Egypt’s commercial capital. After another explosion of cheering the Pat-riarch Photius I., accompanied by the head master of the Hellenic community’s schools, walked among the long files of pupils of the schools, who formed a cordon between the speakers and guests and the crowd. His Beatitude addressed words of enoonragement and commendation to the youths, urging them to work bard and follow in the path of virtue. The buffet was then thrown open and a hand¬some repast was partaken of and the memorable ceremony came to an end. Afterwards a procession was formed of the pupils, beaded by their band, mi the head¬master and professional staff, who went to the Greek quarter and played a selection of music outside the houses of Messrs. Benachi, Sina¬dino, Salvago, and Zervodaohi. Among the decisions of the Council of Ministers held on Saturday afternoon are the following Mr. Kirkwood James is appointed to study a project for the drainage of Cairo. A new railway station is to be built at Halk El Gamal on the Delta Light Railway, between Atfeh and Edfina. The draft decree dealing with the giving of information to the provincial authorities on. the appearance of cotton worm in any locality, is approved. A new company known as the Express Nile Steamer Company is sanctioned. A newmafran, known as the Mafran Benshir, is to be constructed at Minieh. The Council also approved of the abolition of taxes formerly imposed on boats on Lake Menzaleh. THREATENED BARBERS’ STRIKE. The Unione Internazionale dei Parruchieri Lavoranti of Cairo held a meeting on Friday evening at the Brasserie Fleisch, when some 60 members of the union were present. It was unanimously decided to demand from the masters the closing of their shops entirely on Sunday daring the summer months, from the 1st May to the 30th September, and to fix the Working hours during week-days from 7.30 a.m. to 8.30 p.m., with an interval of two hours in the middle of the day for meals, instead of one hour and a half, as at present Should the masters not concede these concessions in full by to-day at the latest, the barbers intend going on strike. It is expected that a com¬promise will be arrived at when the oommittee of the union go round this morning for the answers of the masters. GREEK INDEPENDENCE DAY. Satarday being the 85th anniversary of the declaration of Greek independence the diploma¬tic agencies and consulates in Cairo flew their respective flags. A Thanksgiving Service, which was very largely attended, was held at the Gre'k Orthodox Hameiwi Cathedral at 10 a.m. The personnel of the Greek Diplomatic Agency and Consulate and all the notables of the colony attended the service, over which the Patriarch presided. This service, which lasted an hour, was followed by a reception at the Greek Agency. In the evening a meeting was held at the Greek Club, where M. Boukavalaa delivered an eloquent and a patriotic address to an en¬thusiastic audience. A.S.C. SHEM EL NESSIM MEETING. BRITISH RIFLE CLUB (ALEX> The first deliberate firing spoon competition of this season will take place, on Mustapha Range, next Satarday, 14th inst., commencing at 2.30 p.m. Practice same time.
